Planned Changes to Improve Safety:
 
The WestRock West Point Mill has recently hired two safety managers and a team of Human Resources personnel who are implementing new programs to encourage engagement among hourly and salaried personnel.  Activities include a new Concern Reporting” system in which potential safety issues are entered into a database, and then addressed by teams of personnel from all areas of the Mill.   
 
The Mill has ongoing programs designed to identify and implement safety improvements, including, but not limited to, the performance of periodic safety meetings, safety and operating procedure training required under the OSHA PSM and EPA RMP regulations, and the review of the facility’s process safety information on a routine basis, including during any management of change review.

Employee Participation
 
The Mill actively encourages employee participation at all levels of development, implementation, and maintenance of the RMP program at the West Point Mill.  Employees are provided access to process hazard analyses and other information required to be developed under the RMP regulations.
 
Hot Work Permit
 
The Mill maintains an active Hot Work Program.  Personnel implement a permit system that is designed to prevent fires.  It outlines the Fire Watch responsibilities, the period for work to be conducted, equipment to be worked on, the responsible individual for the work, and signatures/approval of the supervisor, operating department personnel, and safety personnel.  Hot Work permits are issued for all hot work conducted in RMP Covered Processes.
 
Contractors
 
Mill personnel evaluate contractor safety performance before the contractor commences work in an RMP Covered Process.  Mill personnel provide contractors with applicable safety information that address the hazards in the areas where they will be working at the West Point Mill.  
 
Five-Year Accident History
 
The Mill maintains a five-year accident history pertaining to releases of RMP Covered Process chemicals resulting in on-site deaths, injuries, or significant property damage or known off-site deaths, injuries, property damage, environmental damage, evacuations, or sheltering in place.  There have been no applicable accidents in the previous five-year period.
 
Emergency Response Program
 
The Mill is a Non-Responding Mill under 40 CFR Part 68.90.  The Mill maintains an emergency response plan. The local fire department and LEPC

orders for repairs, inspection and testing.  Critical safety and environmental pieces of equipment are given top priority.
 
Management of Change
 
The Mill has a Management of Change policy and guidance procedures to implement a review process when any component of the RMP Covered Process is modified, replaced, or upgraded beyond replacement in kind components or design.  Quality control procedures reside on an electronic Share Point site available to operators and are tied into interlock protection mechanisms built into the process so operators cannot willingly make changes to quality control operating procedures without prior approval.
 
Pre-Startup Safety Review
 
The Mill has a policy indicating the necessity to perform pre-startup safety reviews for new RMP Covered Processes and prior to implementing a significant modification or changes to safety mechanisms (as detailed at 40 CFR 68.77(a)) to a RMP Covered Process.  Documentation is in place to demonstrate that a pre-startup safety review was completed prior startup of a new, or significantly modified equipment, or if safety mechanisms were changed in a RMP Covered Process.
 
Compliance Audits
 
The Mill conducts audits of RMP Covered Processes at least every three years.  The most recent audit was conducted in 2021.  The audits consist of a records review and evaluation of on-site conditions, which are usually performed by third-party consulting companies with qualified auditors.  
 
Incident Investigation
 
Incident investigations are conducted for incidents that result in, or could reasonably result in, a catastrophic release of a RMP Covered Process chemical.  Investigation teams are comprised of pertinent representatives at the Mill.  Procedures require investigations to be initiated within 48 hours of the incident. Process Hazard Analysis

Process Hazard Analyses (PHAs) are conducted on each RMP Covered Processes every five years, or when the process changes.  PHAs for both the chlorine dioxide and aqueous ammonia processes were last re-evaluated in April 2022.  PHAs are conducted by a team of knowledgeable individuals representing at the minimum, operations, maintenance, engineering, and safety.  PHAs address the hazards of the process, identification of previous incidents that had a likely potential for a catastrophic release, engineering, and administrative controls applicable to the hazards.

Operating Procedures
 
Written operating procedures are maintained by the Department responsible for the RMP Covered Processes.  Copies of the procedures are reviewed regularly by operations personnel and are readily available on the Mill Electronic Share Point Site. Standard Operating Procedures and Policies relating to the Mill RMP Covered Processes are available electronically on the Mill Share Point Site.
 
Training
 
The Mill provides on-the-job and classroom training to employees responsible for operating the RMP Covered Processes.  The trainees must demonstrate to the satisfaction of the supervisor that they have the skills and knowledge to perform the required duties prior to being assigned the responsibilities.  Hazard Communication training is provided to each operations employee.
 
Mechanical Integrity
 
The Mill maintains written instructions for inspection and testing of pressure vessels, storage tanks, piping, emergency shutdown systems, controls, alarms, and interlocks that are part of the RMP Covered Processes.  Tests and inspections follow applicable and acceptable codes and standards.  Inspection and testing are performed at a frequency called for by the applicable codes and more often if test data indicate it is warranted. addition, chlorine dioxide is subject to requirements under the Occupational Safety and Health Administration (OSHA) Process Safety Management (PSM) Standard 29 CFR 1910.119.  Therefore, the processes are subject to RMP Program 3 requirements, and are considered RMP Covered Processes.
 
Chlorine dioxide is manufactured on site for use in the Mill bleach plant.  It is produced by combining sodium chlorate, methanol, and sulfuric acid.  The Mill produces a 10 gram per liter chlorine dioxide solution, which is stored in three aboveground storage tanks. The tanks, piping and generator maximum inventory totals approximately 61,000 pounds.   
 
Ammonia (aqueous, 29%) is purchased for use in the Mill wastewater treatment plant.  The mixture is delivered to the site via tanker truck.  The storage tank, tanker truck and piping maximum inventory totals approximately 37,000 pounds.

Pollution Prevention Program

The Mill has a storm water pollution prevention plan, spill prevention control and countermeasures plan, an emergency action plan that contains an emergency response plan, and operations manuals for offloading chemicals.  These plans outline the procedures in place at the Mill to prevent pollution, and to respond to releases or emergencies.  Prevention measures include training, inspections, integrity testing and engineering controls.

Process Safety Information

Process Safety Information relating to the RMP Covered Processes is divided into three categories:  chemical hazards, process technology, and process equipment.  Process safety information relating to the chemical hazards is included in Safety Data Sheets that are kept in readily accessible locations for Mill employees. Process Safety Information relating to the RMP Covered Processes is generally indicated on process drawings and is referenced in operating procedures and Process Hazard Analysis reports.  Process Safety Information relating to RMP Covered Processes is in equipment files maintained by the Mill E

Accidental Release Prevention and Emergency Response Policies

WestRock CP, LLC Mill (the Mill) management is committed to providing the optimum in employee and public safety and health.  It is the policy of Mill management to assure, as far possible, that every employee has a safe place in which to work.  The Mill management provides the resources necessary to fulfill these commitments.  It is also the policy of the Company to expect each employee, contract employee, and visitor to follow all safety rules and committing to safety.
 
It is Mill policy to ensure adequate emergency response capabilities exist to handle an on-site emergency involving RMP-covered chemicals.  The Mill maintains an emergency response plan that addresses how to respond in the event of chemical releases.  The key is prevention.  The Mill executes RMP policies through employee training, equipment purchases and maintenance, and coordination with local emergency response agencies.

Mill Description

The Mill is located along the northern bank of the Pamunkey River at the intersection of 19th and Main Streets, in West Point, Virginia.  The Mill started operations in 1913 with the construction of a pioneer mill at the head of the York River.  In 1914, Chesapeake Pulp & Paper Company began making pulp, which was sold to other mills.   St. Laurent Paper Products Corporation purchased the Mill in 1997.  In 2001, Stone Container Corporation purchased the Mill from St. Laurent Paper Products Corporation. Rock-Tenn Company purchased the company in 2011, and the company changed names to WestRock in 2015 when it merged with Mead Westvaco.
 
The Mill handles chlorine dioxide and aqueous ammonia, which are chemicals listed in 40 CFR Part 68, the EPA Risk Management Program (RMP) Rule.  The Mill operates under the Standard Industrial Classification (SIC) Code 2611, now recognized under the North American Industrial Classification System (NAICS) Code 32211, one of nine highly hazardous SIC/NAICS codes.
